0: Image copyright Getty Images NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Quebec father has launched a class-action lawsuit against McDonald's, alleging the company's Happy Meals break strict provincial laws against advertising to children. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Since its debut in 1979, the Happy Meal has been a staple of McDonald's menu and a go-to meal option on family road trips. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But some Canadian parents are decidedly unhappy about the hold the fast-food empire has over their children's stomachs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Antonio Bramante is the lead plaintiff in a newly certified lawsuit that alleges McDonald's is unlawfully aiming advertising at children under 13 years of age. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR That would violate the province's strict youth consumer protection laws. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Bramante, a father of three young children, says he eats at McDonald's about once every two weeks on the urging of his children, according to the court documents. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He estimates he has spent hundreds of dollars on Happy Meals, which are children's meals that come with toys. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Quebec father says the toys are often linked to popular film releases and his children often want to return to the restaurant so they can complete their set of toys. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He also claims the restaurant is directly targeting children by displaying the Happy Meals toys at their eye level. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Ice resurfacers are among the toys available in Canada NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "In today's world, parents have to choose their battles. And what's the easiest thing to give into? It's to feed your children," says Joey Zukran, the Montreal-based lawyer who filed the class action on Mr Bramante's behalf. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Quebec prohibits marketing to children under the age of 13, making it one of a handful of jurisdictions in the world to essentially ban all advertising geared towards children. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The province has also had a law since 1980 that restricts marketing unhealthy food to children. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR You may also be interested in: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "McDonald's has a legal obligation to respect that law and they're not, in Quebec at least," Mr Zukran told the BBC. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There are three exceptions, with conditions, to Quebec's advertising law: for ads in children's magazines, for promoting a children's entertainment event, and for advertising via store windows, displays, containers, packaging and labels. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Zukran says he is ready to argue McDonald's is not covered by any of these exceptions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Quebec court judge issued a ruling certifying the lawsuit last week. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Anyone who purchased a McDonald's Happy Meal in Quebec from November 2013, even if they are not Canadian residents, can request to be part of the class action, Mr Zukran says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image caption Children at McDonald's NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It seeks both compensatory and punitive damages and an order to prevent McDonald's from continuing the alleged practice. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR McDonald's has about 300 restaurants in the Canadian province. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In a statement, McDonald's Canada told the BBC it has received the ruling certifying the lawsuit and plans to examine it carefully. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We are aware of our obligations under Quebec's advertising laws and reiterate that we do not believe this class action has merit," it said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR McDonald's is one of the world's biggest distributors of toys in the world, driven in large part by Happy Meals sales. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This is not the first time the Happy Meals toys have been the target of a lawsuit. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In 2015, the US Children's Advertising Review Unit, a self-regulatory body, advised the company to focus its advertising on food and not its Happy Meal toys. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The company agreed to take the advice into consideration for future advertisements. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In 2010, the restaurant chain faced a charge that its advertising violated California consumer protection laws. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The lawsuit, filed by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a nutrition advocacy group based in the US, was eventually dismissed. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The claim that the company exploits children in advertising also made its way into the longest court case in UK history. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The "McLibel" case pitted the fast-food empire against two Greenpeace activists who had distributed leaflets entitled "What's wrong with McDonalds - everything they don't want you to know" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It is estimated McDonald's spent millions in legal fees suing the couple for libel.
